title: A Tiny Germ Breaks a Big Rule of Life
summary: Scientists found a tiny living thing called a microbe that breaks a rule about how life works. All living things use DNA to make proteins, which are like tiny machines that do jobs in cells. DNA has instructions made of three-letter codes called codons. Usually, each codon tells the cell to add one specific part, called an amino acid, to build a protein, or it says 'stop' to finish the protein. But this microbe, named Methanosarcina acetivorans, sometimes ignores the 'stop' signal and adds an amino acid instead, making two different proteins from the same instruction. This shows that life can be a little messy and still work fine. The microbe is part of a group called Archaea and makes methane. Scientists think this trick helps it use a special amino acid to eat a chemical called methylamine, which is found in places like our guts. This discovery might help people with some diseases caused by 'stop' signals that come too early.

background_read: DNA is like a recipe book for living things, with codons as instructions to build proteins. Proteins are important molecules that do jobs in cells, such as helping us grow or fight germs. Usually, each codon has one clear meaning, like 'add this amino acid' or 'stop building.' Scientists thought all life followed this rule strictly, but this microbe shows it can be flexible. This might help us understand how life evolved and find new ways to treat diseases where proteins don't form correctly.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists at the University of California, Berkeley and a microbe called Methanosarcina acetivorans
WHAT: They found the microbe breaks the rule that each codon has one meaning by sometimes ignoring a 'stop' signal to add an amino acid
WHERE: In the microbe, which is part of the Archaea group and makes methane
WHY: This helps the microbe use a special amino acid to eat methylamine and might lead to new treatments for diseases caused by early 'stop' signals

perspectives.description: This shows that life can work with a less precise genetic code, challenging old ideas in biology.
